diagnoses.name: Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the liver, which can be caused by viruses, medications, or alcohol. Symptoms can include fatigue and abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk and scalp. Psoriasis can also affect the nails, leading to onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing episodes of severe swelling in various body parts including the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airways.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs. Can cause fatigue, liver enzyme abnormalities, and a plethora of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. These excess cells thicken your blood, slowing its flow, and can cause plethora.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction
diagnoses.description: Adverse drug reactions can manifest as angioedema, abnormal liver enzymes, fatigue, and more, depending on the medication and the individual's reaction to it.

diagnoses.name: Alcohol-related Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Damage to the liver and its function due to alcohol overconsumption. Symptoms can include abnormal liver enzymes and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: The gradual loss of kidney function. It can sometimes cause a wide range of symptoms including fatigue and abnormalities in liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts within the liver, resulting in abnormal liver enzymes and potentially fatigue over time.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can cause a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, abnormal liver enzymes, and changes in skin and nail health.

diagnoses: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) - associated with basophilia
Hypereosinophilic Syndrome - may rarely present with basophilia
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) - associated with dyspepsia
Peptic Ulcer Disease - associated with dyspepsia
Viral Infections - can cause pneumonia and headache
Anxiety Disorders - can lead to or exacerbate stress cardiomyopathy, dyspepsia, and headache
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Hyperparathyroidism Secondary to Chronic Renal Failure

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to a weakened immune system, potentially causing symptoms such as lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes) and fatigue. It may also contribute to delayed puberty in children and can cause peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: Lupus is an autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and mood lability. Neuropathies can also occur in lupus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease, caused by the Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria, can lead to a variety of symptoms including fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and neuropathies. Mood changes have also been associated with Lyme disease.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is a disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form as nodules in multiple organs. It often presents with lymphadenopathy, fatigue, and can affect the nervous system, potentially leading to neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Hodgkin's Lymphoma is a type of cancer that affects the lymphatic system, commonly presenting with symptoms such as fatigue and lymphadenopathy. It can also lead to delayed puberty and affect the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome (CFS)
diagnoses.description: Chronic fatigue syndrome is a complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue and a variety of symptoms including lymphadenopathy. Though not common, it can be associated with sensory neuropathies and mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a variety of complications including neuropathies. While not directly causing lymphadenopathy, diabetes can impact immune function, potentially indirectly affecting it. Mood lability and fatigue are common in uncontrolled diabetes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system that can cause fatigue, neuropathic pain, and mood swings. While MS does not directly cause lymphadenopathy or delayed puberty, it is a possible consideration given the broad impacts on general health.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: Syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection, can cause a wide range of symptoms during its various stages, including lymphadenopathy, neuropathies, and fatigue. Mood changes can also occur, particularly in neurosyphilis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can lead to fatigue, delayed puberty, and mood swings. While neuropathies are less commonly directly associated, the overall decrease in metabolic function can impact nerve health indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Shares symptoms like cysts and can be associated with insulin resistance, possibly linking to glycemic lability.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reason: Connective tissue disorders encapsulating symptoms like hypermobility; may indirectly affect other systems.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Overlap with endometriosis is common, and symptoms can include ulcers or other gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes (Type 1 or 2)
diagnoses.reason: Could explain glycemic lability. Often needs ruling out due to its prevalence and impact on health.

diagnoses.name: Peptic Ulcer Disease
diagnoses.reason: Directly explains ulcers; stress and hormonal changes could be a link among these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Endometrial Ovarian Cysts
diagnoses.reason: A specific manifestation of endometriosis involving ovarian cysts, directly correlating with two symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyperinsulinemia
diagnoses.reason: Can cause or exacerbate glycemic lability and may overlap with symptoms or causes of PCOS.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Not directly linked to these symptoms but often coexists with Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes and similar systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.reason: Some autoimmune conditions can present with a diverse range of symptoms including hypermobility, ulcers, and glycemic issues.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Another connective tissue disorder marked by hypermobility; less likely due to the specificity of other symptoms but worth considering.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Food allergy or intolerance (e.g., lactose intolerance)
Allergic Reaction (to medication, food, or other allergens)
Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) with associated ear, nose, and throat manifestations
Vasculitis associated with Hepatitis B or C
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with associated immune conditions
Chronic Kidney Disease due to Glomerulonephritis
DRESS Syndrome (Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
